description: •Supervised and mentored a team of six employees responsible for validating and coordinating priority intelligence requirements in the organization’s regional coverage consisting of 20 countries. •Analyzed and evaluated existing intelligence shortfalls and developed risk mitigation strategies which resulted in the deployment of 60 collection platforms totaling over US $700 million. •Led a multi-agency working group responsible for establishing an intelligence organization with a yearly operating budget of US $64.1million. Coordinated all aspects from logistics, human resources, operations requirements, and legal authorities.

description: •Supervised and mentored a team of six employees responsible for validating and coordinating priority intelligence requirements in the organization’s regional coverage consisting of 20 countries. •Analyzed and evaluated existing intelligence shortfalls and developed risk mitigation strategies which resulted in the deployment of 60 collection platforms totaling over US $700 million. •Led a multi-agency working group responsible for establishing an intelligence organization with a yearly operating budget of US $64.1million. Coordinated all aspects from logistics, human resources, operations requirements, and legal authorities.

description: Executive Vice President and Chief Strategic Officer for Leidos. Serves as the corporation’s chief growth officer by developing, implementing and orchestrating the leidos growth strategy in the National Security, Health and Engineering markets. Responsible for developing the growth-related initiatives, plans, and processes to not only achieve all the company’s growth objectives, but also set and achieve a world-class standard for the organizing and execution of a growth strategy in the market segments. Serves as the corporate lead for five functions– Strategy, Mergers & Acquisitions, Communications, Government & Legislative Affairs, and Business Development Leidos is a $6 billion, publically traded corporation that serves the national security, health and engineering markets.

description: Acted as president for one of the three sectors that make up SAIC. Responsible for all intelligence business with the corporation together with a broad defense portfolio. Responsible for an organization of 13,000 employees with an annual revenue of $4 Billion. Provided ground, airborne, maritime and space ISR, sensor development, intelligence systems, cyber security and mission support solutions to a wide customer base.

description: Leads SAIC’s intelligence processing business. Responsible for providing responsive solutions to a wide range of national security customers involving the tasking, processing, exploitation and dissemination of information. Core areas of expertise include digital signals processing, geospatial exploitation, motion imagery exploitation, data mining and visualization, advanced analytics, cloud computing, biometrics and electronic security systems engineering . Full range information technology and tactical communications support is also provided. The organization operates at the CMMI-Development maturity level 3 and operates several ISO 9001 certified locations. The organizations maintains a fully capable mobile platform integration facility in Charleston, SC. Resonsible for more than $1B in revenue and more than 3000 employees.

description: Led the SAIC business unit responsible for full range support to the defense Intelligence community including military services, commands, the Defense Intelligence Agency and portions of the Department of Homeland Security. With more than 3,000 employees in over 100 locations the business unit provides both professional services and systems solutions to its wide customer base. The organization has core competencies in intelligence analysis, motion imagery exploitation, data mining and visualization, biometrics and electronic security systems engineering. The business unit frequently deploys employees into operational areas in support of its customers.

description: -Oversaw all areas of the field station as the Senior watch NCO; responsible for the maintenance and overall operations of the site while contacting key leaders during all exercises and real time situations delivering situational updates on vital information to complete their missions. -Maintained 100% oversight and accountability of the field station’s multi-million dollar equipment suite. -Performed theater and national level Signals Intelligence (SIGINT) mission in response to both the U.S Forces Theater Command and the Combined Forces Command. -Responsible for expert quality control of time-sensitive reports for a 24-hour world mission with a 99% accuracy rating. -Served as a front line supervisor for over 70 U.S. Army and local national Soldiers; responsible for the health, welfare and professional development, training readiness and discipline of the unit. -Developed and executed weekly training that increased the overall combat readiness and technical expertise by maintaining a 100% readiness status.

description: -Served as the Special Projects Team lead of the Signals Development (SIGDEV) Directorate at the National Security Agency/Central Security Service Texas, supervising multiple joint-service and civilian personnel – recognized as the “Military Performer of the Year” for exemplary performance within the section. -Processed and analyzed a comprehensive and definitive description of foreign targets using numerous strategic computer databases to process intelligence information utilized by national-level organizations. -Served as the primary tasking manager for the Network Development; Target Development and Analysis team in SIGDEV – trained multiple tasking managers across four division offices in tasking techniques relevant to the NSA wide database migration effectively decreasing tasking errors by 75%. -Developed a mission oriented training program for operationally inexperienced Soldiers resulting in a 100% first-time certification rate of qualified analysts. -Demonstrated expertise and superior target knowledge which led to selection by SIGDEV leadership to regularly brief site commanders on mission production. -Prepared Soldiers for deployment by training them in Geospatial Metadata Analysis which is a critical technique in support of combat operations. -Produced crucial analysis on high interest targets – results verified critical role of Cryptologic Support Team Digital Network Intelligence analysts and briefed to the Director of the National Security Agency. -Created and maintained a target tracking accountability database providing analysts the ability to locate target information in a centralized location. -Assessed and recommended changes to the tactical and national target process improving the analytical focus of the Divisional assets.

description: Chief Master Sergeant Troy L. Eden is the Command Chief, National Air and Space Intelligence Center, Wright-Patterson AFB, Ohio. As the senior enlisted leader of more than 3,100 personnel, Chief Eden advises the commander on all matters related to morale, quality of life, discipline, assignments, training, readiness, professional development and effective utilization of all personnel. With four groups, four directorates, and eighteen squadrons, NASIC is the Air Force's analysis center for foreign air, space and specialized intelligence. NASIC provides a broad range of tailored, integrated assessments, products, and services to joint operational forces, national policymakers, and the acquisition community.

description: Current Position: Chief Master Sergeant Troy L. Eden is the Senior Enlisted Advisor for the Defense Intelligence Agency and the Command Senior Enlisted Leader for the Joint Functional Component Command for Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance, Joint Base Anacostia-Bolling, Washington, D.C. His responsibilities include advising the Director on all matters affecting assignment, training, utilization, readiness, professional development, and quality of life of over 16,500 joint active duty, reserve component, and civilian personnel. In his component capacity he supports the Commander by coordinating with the US Strategic Command headquarters staff and senior personnel on administration and implementation of command policy. The Defense Intelligence Agency is the premier provider of all-source analysis and finished intelligence to warfighters, national security planners, and policymakers to prevent strategic surprise and deliver decision advantage. The Joint Functional Component Command for Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance recommends allocation of ISR capabilities to satisfy strategic/high-priority combatant command and national operational and intelligence requirements; advocates for ISR capabilities; and provides functional support for USSTRATCOM's other missions. Chief Eden’s military education includes the Airmen Leadership School (Levitow winner), Non-commissioned Officer Academy (Distinguished Graduate), Senior Non-commissioned Officer Academy (Distinguished Graduate), Chief Master Sergeant Leadership Course, Senior Enlisted Joint Professional Military Education Course, and Keystone Command Senior Leadership Course. He has also completed the United States Air Force Senior Leadership Course - Gettysburg Leadership Experience, Center for Creative Leadership Development Course, United States Air Force Enterprise Management Seminar, University of Virginia Darden School of Business, and the Strategic Mindset Seminar, Washington, DC.

description: As the senior enlisted leader of a Wing with over 5,500 active, guard, reserve, and civilian Airmen, Chief Eden advises the commander on issues affecting assignment, training, utilization, readiness, professional development, and quality of life of all personnel. The 480th ISR Wing exploits information from U-2, Global Hawk, and Predator platforms. As a globally networked Wing, the 480th Airmen provide regionally focused, actionable intelligence to component commanders and national-level decision makers.

description: A 27 year career included assignments in the Infantry, Logistics, Medical Service and Military Intelligence branches. There were several positions of increasing authority which included Counterintelligence Team Leader at the Army Research Laboratory, Senior Combat Developer for Army Cyber Command a span of several years at the National Security Agency / Central Security Service as a detailed military officer: Action Officer in the Information Warfare Support Center, Chief of the Global Team in the Tailored Military Planning Office, Chief of Space Operations and Functional Team Lead for Electronic Warfare in the Combined Military Planning and Assess Strategies Office. Prior to that, Mr Carpenter worked as the Technology Plans Officer at the Joint Task Force for Global Network Operations, the Executive Officer of the Army Material Commands G2 (Intelligence & Security) office, Division Staff Operations Officer and Command Security Manager for 77th RRC.

description: Served as Ft. Gordon Garrison Operations NCO assisting the Senior Enlisted Leaders with all aspects of the Fort Gordon operations. Was routinely called on to support, coordinate, and train soldiers on all aspects of combat operations training within the unit; primary person in charge of all support shops for the unit to include personnel management, security, plans and operations and supplies and repair for the organization (S1-4). Assisted in the operations of all of Fort Gordon’s landscaping and environmental repairs; assisted in the coordination of the Installation Support Platoon, coordinating the training and of parade and burial details for Central and eastern Georgia and Western South Carolina.

description: Served as the Planner and Coordinator for the 527/719 MI Battalion consisting of over 600 personnel; Supervised the Plans and Operations Group which coordinated all Land Request’s, Ammunition planning and distribution; personally responsible for Pick-up, transport and delivery of ammunition; requesting and delivering of all food, water and fuel for all Training exercises and weapons ranges; coordinated all movement plans for the unit with the South Korean Government. Arranged all training classes and trainers to ensure the Battalion was properly certified in all required area. Additionally responsible for Drivers Training, Nuclear Biological and Chemical Training, Served as the Brigade Area’s Anti-Terrorism Coordination and Training Officer and coordinated all Anti-terrorism and Force protection measures for a full ¼ of Camp Humphrey’s S. Korea perimeter fence.

description: Served as the HOC 741st Military Intelligence Battalions Platoon Sergeant, Responsible for the coordination of the Battalions Service shops S-1 through S-4, manning and work flow for all assigned personnel. Was assigned as the Company’s senior training coordinator and facilitator due to extensive knowledge of all combat tasks. Was responsible for Pick-up, transport and distribution for the Battalions ammunition; coordinated and ran the unit’s special emphasis physical training program ensuring all soldiers met or exceeded all standards; Assisted in the workings and support of six National Security Agency/ Central Security Service work/ Internship programs; Assisted in the coordination and running of the INSCOM Non-Commissioned Officer of the Year Competition.Coordinated and manned the Joint Language Center ensuring all Military Linguists were trained to and above the Army standards, commended for the number of above average scores obtained during testing.. Established, Developed, and ran the Battalions Volunteer program within the community, provided manning, mentorship and leadership in so, supporting two local soup kitchens and one Elementary School. Also coordinated with both CSC and SAFE security companies for profit, providing these companies with augmented security at all Baltimore, M&T Bank Stadium events to include Football, Lacrosse, and Concerts with all profits going towards the unit’s morale events

description: Supervised and operated the only fully functional forward deployed Communications and Repair Shop (C&S) in the CENTCOM Area Kuwait. Responsible for the maintenance and readiness of 26 large node communications packages (radio and satellite), 15 tactical mobile communications packages valued at over 22 Million dollars. Coordinated all test, maintenance and diagnostic equipment and its use to ensure workability of all equipment and arranging properly timed maintenance of all communications equipment. Coordinated, organized and tested more than 22- 52’ foot trailers of electrical equipment, circuit boards and repair parts back into the Army Inventory valued at $5.67 Million dollars and over 6,000 items; personally logging over 560 hours bench testing time. Additionally serves as the Combat Service Associate Representative (CSA) and Senior Supply Support Activity Representative (SSA). Later repaired and restored a damaged and non-functional Large Extension Node (LEN) AN/TTC-46 to 100% functionality, manned and deployed communications package to CP Beuhring, Kuwait in support of operations during OIF III.

description: Served as the Subject Matter Expert responsible for the Development and Implementation of the 25Q, 25F Military Occupational Skills (MOS) and the Development of the 25N MOS from inception to the Initial Entry Soldiers. Developed and reviewed lesson plans, Programs of Instruction (POI), and 25Q,25F and 25N manuals recommending changes to the Army Correspondence Course Program (ACCP), Field Manuals (FM) and Training Evaluation Programs; responsible for reviewing waiver requests for Reserve and National Guard components. Specialized in developing simulations training for High Capacity Line of Sight radio’s (HCLOS), Joint Network Node (JNN)/(BNN) ensuring the Army continued to upgrade its training materials to include Video programs and Video Interactive software.

description: • Utilizes knowledge of intelligence and analysis and how it relates to law enforcement, counter-terrorism, fire/emergency medical services, emergency management, critical infrastructure protection, public health and/or cyber security with utilizing Imagery Analysis (IMINT) and facial recognition. • Knowledge and ability to apply relevant laws, statutes and regulations associated with the agency’s mission. • Ability to conduct a wide range of quantitative and qualitative research, including large amounts of data from Open Source and Imagery intelligence. • Ability to communicate effectively, orally and written and present accurate information in a logical sequence. • Supports and has a direct impact on the Baltimore Police Department by assessing the value of material from internal data bases and social media, turning it into actual intelligence, based on research, followed by the reporting of the analysis. • Conducts internet research to aid in investigative searches while working with detectives and other intelligence analysts in order to create concrete cases against wanted criminals.

description: • Served as an Intelligence Analyst on a U.S. Government counterterrorism program • Performed research and analysis on data and write reports, adhering to tight time lines and strict quality guidelines, using numerous U.S. Government databases with emphasis on Human Intelligence (HUMINT) and Signal Development (SIGDEV). • Was responsible for the analysis and validation of a wide variety of information which supports several facets of U.S. Government counterterrorism programs and contributes to information on potential terrorist threats. • Disseminated new reports to Intelligence and Law Enforcement communities using multiple communication nodes. • Performed basic, preliminary assessments on cyber incidents as they come to the attention watch desk in order to prioritize and properly administer them. • Performed both open- and closed-source research which consisted of locating and collating unclassified information on a specific topic or person/group that is made available by individuals or corporate entities for general or specific consumers. • Provided analytical support to augment field monitoring activities, critical technical collection and the development of preliminary analytical conclusions. • Collaborated with Cyber analysts in order to ensure accuracy of information at hand and verification of collection of the multi-sourced intelligence for exploitation opportunities. • Monitored multiple communications nodes for updates concerning previously reported threats, incidents, and advisories.

description: Supported the U.S. Army by acquiring and maintaining linguistic studies for over 200 Soldiers stationed at Fort George G. Meade, MD. Established training events locally or worldwide depending upon the needs of the individual Soldiers. Maintained the budget for language studies and coordinated with U.S. Government entities in order to share course not yet filled by civilian personnel. Supplied the Brigade’s language library with updated language material. Attended conferences regarding the current trends and issues regarding language training for military personnel.

description: • Supported efforts of the National Security Agency/Central Security Service (NSA/CSS) regarding language training enterprise wide in the Associate Directorate for Education and Training (ADET). • Uploaded and removed technical data onto specific servers in order for classes to be available via the internet for NSA personnel enterprise wide via e-Content for documentation and processing. • Updated and created ADET’s web pages for the language organizations with upcoming courses, immersion opportunities, meetings, etc. using CommonSpot; Created and managed the Language Learning Center’s (LLC) website utilizing Dreamweaver and Fireworks. • Performed research on the trends language classes have undergone during the past five years regarding the scores from the Defense Language Proficiency Test (DLPT); Created PowerPoint presentations on data pulled on the DLPT scores to show if programs are successful or failing. • Account manager that created language learning accounts for NSA personnel who need language training to enhance their mission capabilities.

description: • Transcribed all-source language materials; performed research and target analysis of research and target analysis of technical foreign language material. • Coordinated with senior analysts and subject matter experts to determine potential intelligence value and set handling priorities. • Provided direct language support and first-look analysis of targets (SIGDEV); recommended items for further collection and exploitation. • Monitor multiple communications nodes (multiple network-based computer notification and information sharing applications; multiple telephonic communications circuits; other inter- and intra-agency communications systems) for reports concerning cyber-centric threats and advisories. • Chosen above higher-ranking peers to serve as Company-level Administrative NCO, managing over 150 Soldiers, as well as office Noncommissioned Officer in Charge (NCOIC) over a team of four Soldiers. • Chosen above higher-ranking peers to serve as the Army Program Manager for the Military Language Analyst Program (MLAP). Team Leadership • Managed and advised the career development path of over 30 Language Analysts while motivating and sustaining strong focus and high expectations for performance by recommending specific National Cryptologic School courses needed to fulfill the job qualification requirements. • Briefed program to incoming personnel and higher ranking officials in order to promote the program and to get awareness to different military units world-wide, while explaining how the program is beneficial to those who would also be eventually separating from the military.

description: Watch Officer responsible for providing situational awareness of National Security Agency / Central Security Service Threat Operations Center (NTOC) activities to Cyber Command leadership and coordinating National Cyber Protection Team support to joint, interagency, and multinational equities. Planner responsible for developing, integrating, and synchronizing defensive cyberspace effects across the Department of Defense Information Network (DODIN). Leveraged signals-intelligence techniques within cyberspace to achieve US policy objectives and defend the Nation’s information infrastructure. First Captain from the Psychological Operations Branch ever selected to serve in a strategic level, interagency cyber billet.

description: Commander directly responsible for the command, control, training, administration, operations, logistics, and combat readiness of a 15-man Psyop Detachment. Trained, advised, and assisted up to division size indigenous or coalition force elements in the conduct of information operations. Independently developed, planned, resourced, and executed a predeployment training plan for six Tactical Psyop Teams and a multimedia production element. Deployed in support of Operation Enduring Freedom; managed a national-level special operations program, employing six Tactical Psyop Teams across all of Afghanistan. Oversaw creation of information operations doctrine and standard operating procedures adopted by the entire Afghan National Army. Developed the first NATO sponsored, operational-level information operations planner course for Afghan Special Operations Forces, held at the NATO School, Oberammergau, Germany.

description: Commander directly responsible for the command, control, training, administration, operations, logistics, and combat readiness of a 10-man Psyop Detachment supporting strategic objectives in the US European Command area of responsibility. Trained, advised, and assisted up to a Brigade size element of NATO partnered forces. Managed a national level program that achieved US strategic objectives within Europe, through employment of four Regional Psyop Teams. Deployed to a European nation, in support of Operation Enduring Freedom, to prepare a NATO special operations partnered brigade to conduct information operations in Afghanistan.

description: Supervisor directly responsible for the health and welfare of 2 Warrant Officers, 7 Non-commissioned Officers, and 7 soldiers, as well as planning of all operations conducted by a combined aviation task force, both while deployed to Afghanistan and at home station. Daily duties included analysis of aviation asset allocation, intelligence fusion, logistics planning, coordination with multiple US and Coalition military partners, as well as mission approval briefings to senior officers. Deployed in support of Operation Enduring Freedom; oversaw the planning of over 2000 multi-aircraft combat aviation operations involving 38 airframes and over 650 Soldiers. Developed and implemented a novel system to plan, track, and execute the Task Force’s daily mission requirements. Planned and coordinated the movement of 16 aircraft from redeployment to maintenance depots within the US.

description: Develops and maintains labor and equipment resource loading and other equipment capacity utilization for three production facilities. Applies statistical and analytical skills to gather data, analyze, quantify, and interpret significance in support of business decisions. Analyzes demand information, forecasts, sales orders, machine and labor capacity to provide loading information to senior management. Technical lead for four production planners. - SAP Super User - Developed a functional Excel template set for mapping almost 600 Oracle routings and 70 work centers. - As a leader of a team, we developed template models for all routings in Oracle and implemented these new routings in less than one month, saving $80,000 below the cost of a consultant-based solution. - Mapped Oracle routings over to SAP for over 1500 part numbers. - Created an method of Rough Cut Capacity Planning to level the plant's load and allow the plant's leadership to determine how to address potential limitations well before volume spikes arrive. - Put a canister conversion process into place that allowed the Chemical Vapor Deposition (CVD) division to go from $1 million over budget in capitalization to $400,000 under budget. First year alone re-purposed over 400 canisters, and have realized a cost avoidance of $1.5 million in the first three years.

description: Production control and planning, work order management, CRP, DRP, RCCP, purchasing. - As a production planner, redesigned the Bill of Material schema to align department’s material structures with current business processes. The plan is based on appropriate use of JIT/Kanban, and continuous material assembly methodologies. This resulted in an immediate reduction of $25,000 of on-hand materials and better visibility of demand and capacity restraints. This also resulted in opening up over 50 warehouse locations. - As a production supervisor, used lean methods to flow rework of the plant’s discrepant material into a linear model. This, along with an associated change in paperwork flow, reduced average time reconciling the related documentation to less than one work shift.

description: As the Specialty Instruction Committee Chief for the US Army's Intelligence Center and School: responsible for the development and content for all Army officer training which was specific to the Army's intelligence disciplines (HUMINT, SIGINT, and IMINT). - Updated 80% of the Signals Intelligence course during a continuous rotation of instruction by implementing specific modules from class to class. - Converted portions of the courses to distance learning format, minimizing training costs of each student trained. -------------------------------------------------------- As a Signals Intelligence Staff Officer: Served as a member of the NSA's highly selective Junior Officer Cryptologic Career Program, whose purpose was to address issues throughout the agency that could not be resolved using normal processes or timelines. - One of only 5 officers selected for a liaison tour supporting CIA operations. - Managed a work center of over 400 personnel and $500 million of equipment. - Provided assessments and impact advice to senior military and civilian agency heads. -------------------------------------------------------- As a Company Commander: responsible for the training, health, welfare, and morale of 212 personnel, including 5 officers. - Improved the company’s status in every area measured during my term as commander. -------------------------------------------------------- As an Air Defense Artillery Battalion Intelligence Officer: provided intelligence for air threat to 3rd Armor division and missile threat to VII Corps during operations Desert Shield and Desert Storm. - Supervised one officer, four non-commissioned officers and three enlisted personnel. - Part of the team that developed a first-ever application of a tactical missile defense network protecting the US Army's VII corps with over 100,000 personnel in combat. - Scored a rare "Perfect" rating on quarterly inspections of the intelligence section's processes and procedures.

description: From July 2009 - August 2013 the MLI contract was posted for rebidding annually. Thereby I worked for 3 distinct companies over 4 years, while holding the same position. MLI duties included the following, but were not limited to: • Classroom instruction of Modern Standard Arabic to joint service personnel and overseeing the incremental examinations of language progression at the DLI/FLC Middle East Schools. Over 5000 hours of classroom and laboratory instruction provided. Test control, administration, grading and processing of results conducted. Instruction consisted of accredited and published curriculum material as well as personally developed lessons to incorporate Final Learning Objectives, ensuring these tasks were uniquely designed to meet requirements for future application with tangible ILR levels assigned. • Trained to employ resources such as Smart Boards, iPads and Macbook Pro Tablet PCs to develop learning materials. Assignments also delivered using: BlackBoard / Sakai, RapidRote, and SharePoint. • Team Lead August 2011-August 2013. Produced weekly and monthly reporting of hours taught and curricula items produced by 3 contract MLI’s to the contract holder for accountability and billing. • Long term planning and scheduling of the 63 week length course to ensure milestones for each semester and course completion were met for multiple and overlapping iterations of the training. • Liaison between US service members and native language instructors, at times diffusing conflicts with proven resolutions and bridging the gap created by language barriers. Additionally, the primary link to service unit representatives; attending weekly meetings to address student’s status, attendance and disciplinary issues needing correction. • Identified and created action plans for struggling students, tailored to their learning style. Moves included recycling or restarting, thereby setting students up for future success upon completion.

description: Commands a Theater Intelligence Brigade, leading 2,100 soldiers and civilians delivering multi-discipline intelligence to United States Army South and Combatant Commanders worldwide. Delivers advanced capabilities, including all-source analysis; signals intelligence; aerial Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance (ISR); human intelligence, including the Army's only active duty interrogation battalion; and counterintelligence to answer global intelligence requirements. Supervises multi-discipline individual and collective intelligence training at the Intelligence and Security Command (INSCOM) Detention Training Facility (IDTF). Manages $71M in property and executes a $27M annual budget. Responsible for the health, morale, welfare, and discipline of the Brigade's Soldiers and Civilians, as well as support to our Family Members

description: Responsible for the timely collection, analysis and dissemination of all-source intelligence support for 24/7/365 global cyber operations in a 20,000-strong Army Component with a mission spanning Army generating and operating forces. Responsible for all aspects of security and Intelligence Oversight. Responsible for Intelligence Preparation of the Environment and Targeting Intelligence support to full-spectrum cyber operations. Synchronized Army and Intelligence Community cyber intelligence efforts to maximize intelligence support to the Army. Responsible for intelligence training and support to cyber training, including information assurance, in the Army. Provided intelligence support to Army planning, programming and acquisition relating to cyber, networks and communications.

description: Department of the Army G3/5/7 Army Cyberspace Task Force Plans Officer and U.S. Army Intelligence and Security Command (INSCOM) Liaison Officer. Provided expertise regarding network warfare/cyberspace operations and multi-discipline intelligence capabilities, organizations and procedures. Led input to the Army Campaign Plan Decision Brief for Army cyberspace forces and capabilities, to include development of the Army Component to United States Cyber command. Contributed to planning for all aspects of cyber force structure, doctrine, training, materiel, leadership, personnel and facilities. Developed Army plans and orders. Worked closely with U.S. Army Training and Doctrine Command to develop cyberspace concepts and capabilities assessment. Supervised planning involving over $15 million in year of execution funding and Army force structure for over 20,000 personnel.

description: Commanded a battalion of 452 Soldiers and civilians delivering Signals Intelligence (SIGINT) and Computer Network Operations capability. Responsible for all aspects of leadership, to include the readiness, health, morale and welfare of the battalion’s Solders and civilians. Deployed individuals and teams to operational theaters of war to provide critical intelligence support. Ensured tactical, technical and personal readiness of all deploying Soldiers. Provided intelligence reachback to deployed forces. Led execution of the Army Foundry Program for Signals Intelligence, providing comprehensive training for Army units. Directed an annual budget of over $3 million.

description: Deputy commanding officer for a Brigade of over 1,600 Soldiers and civilians conducting full-spectrum cryptologic operations, including signals intelligence (SIGINT), information assurance, and computer network operations (CNO) directly and through the National Security Agency (NSA) in support of national and Army requirements and objectives from locations around the world. Supervised and led Brigade primary and special staff. Principal advisor to the Brigade Commander on personnel, security, operations, logistics, financial and information management. Supervised programming through execution of 16 intelligence and operating budgets totaling over $20 million. Coordinated with U.S. Army Intelligence and Security Command, the National Security Agency/Central Security Service, garrison, and other services. Performed dues as Brigade Commander as required.

description: Army Fellow working for the Director, National Security Agency (NSA)/Chief, Central Security Service (CSS). Supported the NSA Director, Deputy Director and Chief of Staff as a senior intelligence staff officer addressing projects and issues assigned by the Director, preparing senior officials for high-level meetings and coordinating Agency events. Provided analysis and recommendations regarding the future of the United States Cryptologic System and intelligence programs involving billions of dollars and national security posture. Coordinated between the NSA, the Office of the Director of National Intelligence and other Intelligence Community partners. Contributed to NSA/CSS and Service Cryptologic Element (SCE) goals and promotes a strong relationship between NSA/CSS, SCEs and national and tactical customers.

description: Supervised and managed all-source intelligence production to evaluate threat actions, identify trends, and forecast insurgent activities. Provided intelligence to the Deputy Chief of Staff for Intelligence (DCSINT/C2), Commanding General, staff and subordinate units to shape campaign planning, operations and targeting for a Coalition involving over 160,000 troops from 28 nations. Participated in national-level discussions to contribute to the intelligence community’s understanding of the insurgency in Iraq. Coordinated resource and administrative issues; served as branch chief when required.
